comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Julius Petersen (1878-1941) and Wilhelm Benignus (1861-1930), writer. There was also a famous Danish mathematician Julius Peter Christian Petersen who invented graph theory but this is not him.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Julius Petersen was a German literary scholar de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julius_Petersen_%28Literaturwissens... www.wissen.de/lexikon/petersen-julius According to The New York Times, March 3, 1912 he was Professor in Yale in 1912.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Wilhelm Heinrich Benignus (1861–1931) was a German writer (according to de.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liste_deutschsprachiger_Schriftstel...) "Hermann Wilhelm Heinrich Benignus, born on February 17, 1861 in Heilbronn, enrolled as an ordinary student at the Stuttgart Technical High School. He came to America in 1882. Here his destiny underwent several changes. He is currently a newspaper correspondent and illustrator. He lives in Atlantic City, New Jersey. He wrote Songs of the World River, Compositions and his newest illustrated book on the American landscape, Voices of the Water, which poetically glorifies the unique beauty of the American landscape. " Source: www.archivaria.com/BdDA/BdDA6.html An opus of him in English: www.google.com/url?sa=t&rct=j&q=&esrc=s&s... See photograph Page 10

comment.author: 33593953@N02
comment._content: B-59: Thanks for the further information on Benignus. We have lovely portraits of him (not digitized) in our reading room Biographical File, received by the library through copyright deposit in 1913. In two of them, he holds a copy of his book Stimmen der Wasser--even his pose seems poetic!
